The more I read of them, the more I became convinced that they had a profounder insight into the mysteries of nature than the moderns. Theirs was a philosophy which was not merely a collection of dry facts, but a living, breathing system, which seemed to be in harmony with the very soul of man. I had been particularly struck by the writings of Plato, and had spent many hours poring over his dialogues, trying to grasp the full meaning of his ideas. His notion of the universe as a vast, interconnected web of being, in which every part was linked to every other, had fascinated me, and I had often found myself lost in thought, trying to follow the threads of his reasoning. And yet, despite my admiration for the Greeks, I had not been able to shake off the feeling that there was something missing, something that the ancient philosophers had not been able to provide. It was a feeling that had grown stronger with time, and had been reinforced by my conversations with M. Krempe, who had seemed to me to be a man of great learning, but also of great narrowness of mind. His views on the subject of natural science had been so limited, so conventional, that I had begun to wonder if he was not a representative of a whole class of men, who were more interested in preserving the established order of things than in seeking out the truth. And so, as I walked home, I found myself pondering the question of how it was that men like M. Krempe could be so blind to the obvious, so deaf to the call of the unknown. Was it a lack of imagination, a lack of courage, or simply a lack of curiosity? I did not know, but I was determined to find out, and to follow my own path, no matter where it might lead.

en_results: The face of the damned, and yet I felt an unholy fascination with it, as if drawn by some morbid curiosity to behold the depths of depravity that seemed to stare back
en_results_raw: The face of the damned, and yet I felt an unholy fascination with it, as if drawn by some morbid curiosity to behold the depths of depravity that seemed to stare back at me with cold, calculating eyes. His skin was deathly pale, stretched taut over the bones of his skull, and his lips were curled into a snarl that seemed to mock me with its very existence. The air around him seemed to grow colder, heavier, as if the very presence of evil itself had taken on a physical form, and I could feel its dark energy coursing through my veins like a poison. I tried to step back, to turn away from the horror that stood before me, but my feet seemed rooted to the spot, unable to move or look away from the abyss that gazed back at me with an unblinking stare.

es_results_raw: recorría las calles oscuras de la ciudad, rodeado de una niebla espesa que parecía adherirse a sus ropas como una segunda piel. Sus ojos, dos agujeros negros como la noche, parecían estar mirando a través de mí, como si pudieran ver el alma que late en mi pecho. en_first_half: “Very well, and very happy, only a little uneasy that they hear from you so seldom. By the by, I mean to lecture you a little upon their account myself. But, my dear Frankenstein,”
en_second_half: continued he, stopping short and gazing full in my face, “I did not before remark how very ill you appear; so thin and pale; you look as if you had been watching for several nights.”
en_results: I must confess that I have been somewhat perplexed by your silence, and I fear that some misfortune may have befallen you. But I must not distress you now, for I see that you are in high
en_results_raw: “I must confess that I have been somewhat perplexed by your silence, and I fear that some misfortune may have befallen you. But I must not distress you now, for I see that you are in high spirits, and I would not wish to mar the pleasure of your letter by any unnecessary anxiety. No, let us speak of something else, and I will reserve my lecture for another time. But tell me, how do you find the climate in your new home? Is it as you had hoped? And how do you like your new friends? I am particularly anxious to hear about your sister, and whether she is settled and happy in her new surroundings. I must confess that I have been a little worried about her, and I am eager to know that she is well and content. But I see that you are not telling me everything, and I must wait until you are ready to share your thoughts with me. In the meantime, I will content myself with the knowledge that you are safe and well, and that you are making the most of your new life. But I must say, my dear Frankenstein, that I do hope you will write to me more frequently in the future, for I am your father, and it is my duty to know that you are happy and thriving. en_first_half: Clerval had never sympathised in my tastes for natural science; and his literary pursuits differed wholly from those which had occupied me. He came to the university with the design of making himself complete master of the oriental languages, and thus he should open a field for the plan of life he had marked out for himself. Resolved to pursue no inglorious career, he turned his eyes toward the East, as affording scope for his spirit of enterprise. The Persian, Arabic, and Sanskrit languages engaged his attention, and I was easily induced to enter on the same studies. Idleness had ever been irksome to me, and now that I wished to fly from reflection, and hated my former studies, I felt great relief in being
en_second_half: the fellow-pupil with my friend, and found not only instruction but consolation in the works of the orientalists. I did not, like him, attempt a critical knowledge of their dialects, for I did not contemplate making any other use of them than temporary amusement. I read merely to understand their meaning, and they well repaid my labours. Their melancholy is soothing, and their joy elevating, to a degree I never experienced in studying the authors of any other country. When you read their writings, life appears to consist in a warm sun and a garden of roses,—in the smiles and frowns of a fair enemy, and the fire that consumes your own heart. How different from the manly and heroical poetry of Greece and Rome!

en_results_raw: engaged in a pursuit which, though new to me, was at least novel, and which, by the very novelty of its difficulties, had the power of absorbing my whole attention. The hours which I had formerly devoted to chemistry and natural philosophy were now occupied by the study of Arabic and Persian, and I found a strange, a new, and an intense pleasure in the acquisition of these languages. The characters, the grammar, and the idioms of the East were to me a boundless ocean, full of mystery and enchantment, and I felt a thrill of delight in every step I made in mastering them. Clerval, who had been my companion in these studies, was a constant source of encouragement and support, and his enthusiasm was contagious, so that I found myself carried along by his zeal, and my own interest in the subject grew with every day. The hours passed rapidly, and I was surprised to find how soon the days had turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, and yet I felt no sense of weariness or satiety, for the novelty of the subject, and the pleasure of the pursuit, kept my mind in a state of constant excitement and eagerness. The more I advanced in my studies, the more I became convinced that I was on the right path, and that the East, with all its mysteries and wonders, was indeed the field for which I was destined. And so, with Clerval by my side, and the languages of the East as our common pursuit, we journeyed on, our spirits high, our hearts full of hope, and our minds full of wonder, into the unknown, and the unexplored.
vi_first_half: Clerval xưa nay không chia sẻ ý thích của tôi về khoa học tự nhiên; những sách vở anh tìm đọc khác hoàn toàn với những gì làm tôi bận trí. Anh đến trường đại học với ý định tự rèn mình tinh thông mọi ngôn ngữ Đông phương, mở ra một lĩnh vực cho kế hoạch đời mình mà anh đã hoạch định. Quyết tâm sẽ không theo đuổi sự nghiệp nào kém vinh quang, anh hướng tầm nhìn về phương Đông: như thể chỉ nơi đó mới đủ tầm vóc cho khao khát được nên công nghiệp của anh. Các ngôn ngữ Ba Tư, Ả Rập và Sanskrit khiến anh chú ý, tôi cũng dễ dàng bị lôi cuốn vào học cùng với anh. es_second_half: anterior dedicación me confortaba el compartir con mi amigo sus estudios, encontrando no sólo formación sino consuelo en los trabajos de los orientalistas. Su melancolía es relajante, y su alegría anima hasta puntos nunca antes experimentados al estudiar autores de otros países. En sus escritos la vida parece hecha de cálido sol y jardines de rosas, de sonrisas y censuras de una dulce enemiga y del fuego que consume el corazón. ¡Qué distinto de la poesía heroica y viril de Grecia y Roma!

Me decía que quería viajar por el mundo, descubrir nuevos lugares y culturas, y aprender de las personas que los habitaban. Me contaba sobre sus propios sueños de convertirse en un experto en lenguas orientales y viajar a lugares como Persia y Arabia para estudiar la historia y la literatura de aquellas civilizaciones. Me impresionaba su entusiasmo y su curiosidad, y a menudo me preguntaba si algún día podría unirme a él en sus aventuras. Pero por ahora, estaba decidido a seguir adelante con sus planes de estudiar en la universidad y hacer de su sueño una realidad. Me alegraba verlo tan motivado y seguro de sí mismo, y esperaba con ansias ver qué lograría en el futuro.
tr_first_half: Clerval doğa bilimine duyduğum ilgiye hiçbir zaman sempatiyle yaklaşmamıştı ve edebî seçimleri de benimkilerden tamamen farklıydı. Üniversiteye Doğu dillerinde tam anlamıyla uzmanlaşmak amacıyla gelmişti, böylece belirlediği hayat planında kendisi için bir yol açmış olacaktı. Şanı şöhreti olmayan bir kariyere atılmamakta kararlı biri olarak gözlerini, yatırımcı ruhuna elverişli bir alan olarak gördüğü Doğu'ya çevirdi. Fars, Arap ve Sanskrit dilleri ilgisini çekiyordu ve aynı çalışmalara girmeye beni de kolayca ikna etti. Başıboşluk beni her zaman rahatsız etmişti ve düşünmekten kaçtığım, eski çalışmalarımdan nefret ettiğim bir zamanda arkadaşımın derslerine eşlik etmek beni çok rahatlatıyordu.
tr_second_half: Oryantalistlerin eserlerinde yalnızca bilgi değil, teselli de buluyordum. Eğlenceden öte bir amacım olmadığı için, Clerval'in aksine bu dillerin lehçeleri hakkında çözümleyici bilgiler edinmeye kalkışmadım. Yalnızca anlamlarını anlamak için okudum ve çabalarımın karşılığını da fazlasıyla aldım. Bu eserler melankolileriyle beni teskin ediyor, neşeli tonlarıyla bana diğer ülkelerin yazarlarını incelerken hiç hissetmediğim türden bir moral aşılıyorlardı. Onları okuduğunuzda hayat sanki sıcacık bir güneşten, güllerle dolu bir bahçeden, adaletli bir düşmanın tebessümü ya da öfkesinden, yüreğinizi yiyip bitiren bir ateşten ibaretmiş gibi hissediyordunuz. The darkness seemed to press in around me, making it difficult to see more than a few feet in front of me. I fumbled in my pocket for a match and lit it, the flame casting flickering shadows on the trees. As I walked, the trees grew closer together, forming a tunnel of branches that seemed to close in around me. I quickened my pace, my heart pounding in my chest. The rustling grew louder, and I could tell that whatever was making the noise was moving towards me. I gripped my walking stick tightly, ready for whatever was coming my way. As I rounded a bend in the path, I caught a glimpse of something moving through the trees. It was a figure, tall and imposing, its features indistinct in the darkness. I froze, my heart racing with fear. The figure drew closer, and I could see that it was a man, dressed in a long coat that seemed to billow behind him like a dark cloud. The man drew closer, and I could see that he was old, his face lined with age and experience. He regarded me with a piercing gaze, his eyes seeming to bore into my very soul. es_second_half: en barca, por el lago. Durante el corto recorrido, vi los relámpagos que, sobre la cima del Mont Blanc, dibujaban las más hermosas figuras. La tormenta parecía avecinarse con rapidez y, al desembarcar, subí a una colina para desde allí observar mejor su avance. Se acercaba; el cielo se cubrió de nubes, y pronto sentí la lluvia caer lentamente, y las gruesas y dispersas gotas se fueron convirtiendo en un diluvio.

es_results_raw: para llegar a la tumba de mi hermano. La luna estaba en su cuarto creciente, y su luz plateada iluminaba el camino que llevaba a la pequeña iglesia donde se encontraba el cementerio. Me sentí un escalofrío al recordar la noche en que mi hermano había sido asesinado, y cómo su cuerpo había sido encontrado en el río. Me acerqué a la tumba, y me detuve un momento a contemplar la inscripción grabada en la lápida. "William, hermano querido, muerto en la juventud, vivirá en mi corazón para siempre". Me sentí un nudo en la garganta al leer esas palabras, y me pregunté si algún día encontraría la paz y la justicia para mi hermano. La noche era silenciosa, solo se escuchaba el canto de los grillos y el susurro del viento a través de los árboles. Me senté en la hierba fresca, y me quedé allí sentado durante un rato, recordando a mi hermano y pensando en el misterio que lo rodeaba. De repente, escuché un ruido detrás de mí, y me di la vuelta para ver quién o qué era. Un hombre estaba allí, parado en la sombra, mirándome con una expresión seria. Me pregunté quién sería ese hombre, y qué quería de mí.

Gerçekten de ilerledi; gökyüzünü bulutlar sardıktan kısa bir süre sonra yağmurun iri damlalarla yağdığını hissettim. Şiddeti birdenbire arttı.

El más alto de ellos, un tipo alto y delgado con gafas, se adelantó y comenzó a explicar que había sido testigo de algo inexplicable en la noche anterior, algo que no podía explicar con palabras. Su voz temblaba ligeramente mientras hablaba, y pude ver un destello de miedo en sus ojos. Me pregunté si estaría mintiendo, pero algo en su tono me hizo dudar. "¿Qué pasó?" le pregunté, tratando de mantener la calma. El tipo se aclaró la garganta antes de comenzar a hablar, y su voz se volvió más firme. "Fue en el parque de diversiones. Estaba allí con mis amigos, disfrutando de la noche, cuando de repente, vi a una mujer que parecía... que parecía no estar allí. No sé cómo explicarlo, pero parecía que no estaba en el mismo tiempo que nosotros. Estaba allí, pero no estaba allí. ¿Entiendes?" Me quedé en silencio, tratando de procesar lo que me estaba diciendo. No sabía qué creer, pero algo en su historia me hizo sentir una sensación de inquietud. ¿Qué había visto realmente ese tipo? ¿Y qué había visto la mujer en el parque de diversiones? Me pregunté si estaría involucrado en algo más profundo de lo que parecía. La noche anterior, en el parque de diversiones, había sido un evento normal, pero ahora parecía que había sido algo más. ¿Qué había pasado allí? ¿Y qué había pasado con la mujer? Me quedé en silencio, tratando de encontrar las palabras adecuadas para preguntarle más. Pero antes de que pudiera hablar, el tipo se interrumpió y me miró con una expresión seria. "No es solo eso", dijo. "Es que... es que la vi antes. La vi en mi infancia. En mi casa. En mi habitación. ¿Cómo es posible?" Me quedé sin aliento, tratando de procesar lo que me estaba diciendo. ¿Qué había visto realmente ese tipo? ¿Y qué había visto la mujer en el parque de diversiones? Justine died, she rested, and I was alive. The blood flowed freely in my veins, but a weight of despair and remorse pressed on my heart which nothing could remove. Sleep fled from my eyes; I wandered like an evil spirit, for I had committed deeds of mischief beyond description horrible, and more, much more (I persuaded
en_second_half: myself) was yet behind. Yet my heart overflowed with kindness and the love of virtue. I had begun life with benevolent intentions and thirsted for the moment when I should put them in practice and make myself useful to my fellow beings. Now all was blasted; instead of that serenity of conscience which allowed me to look back upon the past with self-satisfaction, and from thence to gather promise of new hopes, I was seized by remorse and the sense of guilt, which hurried me away to a hell of intense tortures such as no language can describe.

en_first_half: About this time we retired to our house at Belrive. This change was particularly agreeable to me. The shutting of the gates regularly at ten o’clock and the impossibility of remaining on the lake after that hour had rendered our residence within the walls of Geneva very irksome to me. I was now free. Often, after the rest of the family had retired for the night, I took the boat and passed many hours upon the water. Sometimes, with my sails set, I was carried by the wind; and sometimes, after rowing into the middle of the lake, I left the boat to pursue its own course and gave way to my own miserable reflections. I was often tempted, when all
en_second_half: was at peace around me, and I the only unquiet thing that wandered restless in a scene so beautiful and heavenly—if I except some bat, or the frogs, whose harsh and interrupted croaking was heard only when I approached the shore—often, I say, I was tempted to plunge into the silent lake, that the waters might close over me and my calamities for ever. But I was restrained, when I thought of the heroic and suffering Elizabeth, whom I tenderly loved, and whose existence was bound up in mine. I thought also of my father and surviving brother; should I by my base desertion leave them exposed and unprotected to the malice of the fiend whom I had let loose among them?

Cái lệ ngày nào cổng cũng đóng lúc mười giờ tối, khiến sau lúc đó không ể ở bên hồ được, đã biến nơi ở trong phạm vi tường thành Geneva thành đặc biệt khó chịu đối với tôi. Bây giờ thì tôi tha hồ tự do. Thường thường, đợi cho cả nhà nghỉ đêm rồi, tôi đưa thuyền ra bơi một mình trên mặt nước suốt nhiều giờ. Đôi lúc tôi dong buồm mặc cho gió đưa đi; đôi lúc, chèo ra giữa hồ, tôi mặc con thuyền trôi nổi và thả mình cho những suy tư ủ dột. es_first_half: Por esta época nos trasladamos a nuestra casa de Belrive. El cambio me resultó especialmente agradable. El habitual cierre de las puertas a las diez de la noche y la imposibilidad de permanecer en el lago después de esa hora me hacían incómoda la estancia en la misma Ginebra. Ahora estaba libre. A menudo, cuando el resto: de mi familia se había acostado, cogía la barca y pasaba largas horas en el lago. A veces izaba la vela, y dejaba que el viento me llevara; otras, remaba hasta el centro del lago y allí dejaba la barca a la deriva mientras yo me sumía en tristes pensamientos. Con frecuencia, cuando todo a mi
es_second_half: alrededor estaba en paz, y yo era la única cosa inquieta que vagaba intranquilo por ese paisaje tan precioso y sobrenatural, exceptuando algún murciélago, o las ranas cuyo croar rudo e intermitente oía cuando me acercaba a la orilla, con frecuencia, digo, sentía la tentación de tirarme al lago silencioso, y que las aguas se cerraran para siempre sobre mi cabeza y mis sufrimientos. Pero me frenaba el recuerdo de la heroica y abnegada Elizabeth, a quien amaba tiernamente, y cuya vida estaba íntimamente unida a la mía. Pensaba también en mi padre y mi otro hermano: ¿iba yo con mi deserción a exponerlos a la maldad del diablo que había soltado entre ellos?
es_results: alrededor estaba tranquilo y silencioso, me sentaba en la proa de la barca y contemplaba el reflejo de las estrellas en el agua. El lago parecía un espejo perfecto, reflejando la belleza del cielo nocturno con una precisión sorprendente. Me sentía pequeño y insignificante en ese vasto escenario, y sin embargo, al mismo tiempo, me sentía conectado con algo mucho más grande que yo mismo. La soledad me permitía reflexionar sobre mi vida, sobre mis pensamientos y sentimientos, y sobre las decisiones que había tomado. Me preguntaba si había elegido el camino correcto, si había hecho lo que debía hacer, y si había sido verdaderamente feliz. Pero también me daba
es_results_raw: alrededor estaba tranquilo y silencioso, me sentaba en la proa de la barca y contemplaba el reflejo de las estrellas en el agua. El lago parecía un espejo perfecto, reflejando la belleza del cielo nocturno con una precisión sorprendente. Me sentía pequeño y insignificante en ese vasto escenario, y sin embargo, al mismo tiempo, me sentía conectado con algo mucho más grande que yo mismo. La soledad me permitía reflexionar sobre mi vida, sobre mis pensamientos y sentimientos, y sobre las decisiones que había tomado. Me preguntaba si había elegido el camino correcto, si había hecho lo que debía hacer, y si había sido verdaderamente feliz. Pero también me daba cuenta de que la soledad no era algo negativo, sino algo que me permitía crecer y aprender. Me permitía ver las cosas desde una perspectiva diferente, y encontrar la paz en el silencio y la oscuridad. A medida que pasaban las noches, me sentía más conectado con el lago, con la naturaleza, y conmigo mismo. Me sentía más en armonía con el mundo que nunca antes. Y aunque la soledad a veces me parecía abrumadora, sabía que era un proceso necesario para encontrar la verdadera felicidad. Así que seguía pasando las noches en la barca, sumido en mis pensamientos, y permitiendo que el lago me llevara a lugares desconocidos. Y fue allí, en ese lago, donde encontré una paz interior que nunca antes había conocido.

en_first_half: From Derby, still journeying northwards, we passed two months in Cumberland and Westmorland. I could now almost fancy myself among the Swiss mountains. The little patches of snow which yet lingered on the northern sides of the mountains, the lakes, and the dashing of the rocky streams were all familiar and dear sights to me. Here also we made some acquaintances, who almost contrived to cheat me into
en_second_half: happiness. The delight of Clerval was proportionably greater than mine; his mind expanded in the company of men of talent, and he found in his own nature greater capacities and resources than he could have imagined himself to have possessed while he associated with his inferiors. “I could pass my life here,” said he to me; “and among these mountains I should scarcely regret Switzerland and the Rhine.”

en_results_raw: cheat me into believing that the rugged beauty of these northern counties was not so different from the picturesque landscapes of the Alps. The rolling hills, the verdant valleys, and the sparkling waterfalls all seemed to whisper tales of a distant, yet familiar, homeland. Our hosts, a kind-hearted family who resided in a quaint village nestled between the mountains, took a particular liking to me and my companions. They regaled us with stories of the region's history, from the ancient Celtic tribes to the more recent industrial developments that had transformed the area into a thriving hub of textile production. As we sat by the fire, listening to their tales, I couldn't help but feel a deep connection to this place, as if the rugged beauty of the landscape had awakened a part of me that I never knew existed. The days passed quickly, and before I knew it, we were preparing to leave, but not before our hosts presented us with a small, intricately carved wooden box as a parting gift. It was adorned with symbols and patterns that seemed to dance across its surface, and I couldn't help but wonder what stories it might hold. As we continued our journey northwards, the box remained a constant companion, a tangible reminder of the people and places that had touched our lives in this enchanting corner of England.

es_results_raw: me resultaron muy gratas y significativas, especialmente con un joven pastor llamado John, que nos mostró con gran generosidad su hogar y su familia. A pesar de la brevedad de nuestra estancia, logramos establecer una conexión profunda con ellos, y su hospitalidad y amabilidad nos quedaron grabadas en la memoria. Mientras tanto, la naturaleza nos rodeaba con su majestuosidad, y las montañas nos parecían más altas y más imponentes con cada paso que dábamos. El aire fresco y limpio de la región me hizo sentir renovado y rejuvenecido, y mi espíritu se llenó de una sensación de libertad y aventura. La experiencia en Cumberland y Westmoreland fue una de las más gratificantes de mi viaje, y me permitió recordar la belleza y la simplicidad de la vida en la naturaleza.

en_first_half: All was again silent, but his words rang in my ears. I burned with rage to pursue the murderer of my peace and precipitate him into the ocean. I walked up and down my room hastily and perturbed, while my imagination conjured up a thousand images to torment and sting me. Why had I not followed him and closed with him in mortal strife? But I had suffered him to depart, and he had directed his course towards the mainland. I shuddered to think who might be the next victim sacrificed to his insatiate revenge. And then
en_second_half: I thought again of his words—“I will be with you on your wedding-night.” That, then, was the period fixed for the fulfilment of my destiny. In that hour I should die and at once satisfy and extinguish his malice. The prospect did not move me to fear; yet when I thought of my beloved Elizabeth, of her tears and endless sorrow, when she should find her lover so barbarously snatched from her, tears, the first I had shed for many months, streamed from my eyes, and I resolved not to fall before my enemy without a bitter struggle.

Inquieto y preocupado paseaba de un lado a otro de la habitación, mientras la imaginación me asediaba con mil ideas torturantes. ¿Por qué no lo había perseguido y entablado con él un combate a muerte? Le había permitido escapar y ahora se dirigía hacia el continente. Temblaba al pensar en quién sería la próxima víctima sacrificada
es_second_half: a su insaciable venganza. De pronto recordé sus palabras: «Estaré a tu lado en tu noche de bodas». Esa, pues, era la fecha en la que se cumpliría mi destino. Entonces moriría y, al tiempo, quedaría satisfecha y extinguida su maldad. Esto no me asustaba; pero la imagen de mi querida Elizabeth, derramando lágrimas de inconsolable dolor al ver que su marido le era arrebatado cruelmente, me hizo, por primera vez en muchos meses, prorrumpir en llanto, y decidí no sucumbir ante mi enemigo sin luchar.

es_results_raw: <output>La imagen de mi hermana pequeña, con su sonrisa inocente y sus ojos brillantes, se me apareció en la mente y me llenó de un dolor insoportable. Me sentí culpable por no haber podido protegerla, por no haber podido evitar que cayera en las garras de ese monstruo. Mi mente se llenó de preguntas sin respuesta: ¿Por qué había elegido a mi hermana? ¿Qué había visto en ella que la convirtió en su objetivo? Me sentí impotente y furioso al mismo tiempo, incapaz de hacer nada más que pasear de un lado a otro de la habitación, sintiendo que mi rabia y mi dolor se acumulaban en mi interior. De repente, escuché un ruido en la puerta y me di la vuelta, esperando ver al asesino de regreso, listo para atacar. Pero en lugar de eso, vi a mi mejor amigo, con una expresión de preocupación en su rostro. "¿Qué pasa, amigo mío?" me preguntó, notando mi estado de ánimo. Me sentí aliviado de poder hablar con alguien, de poder compartir mi dolor y mi rabia con alguien que me entendiera. Le conté todo lo que había sucedido, y él me escuchó atentamente, sin juzgarme ni intentar darme consejos. Cuando terminé de hablar, se quedó en silencio por un momento, como si estuviera pensando en algo. Luego, me miró a los ojos y me dijo: "Vamos a encontrar al asesino, amigo mío. Vamos a hacer que pague por lo que ha hecho". Su determinación y su convicción me dieron fuerzas, y juntos decidimos emprender una búsqueda que nos llevaría a través de la ciudad, a través de calles oscuras y peligrosas, en busca de justicia y venganza. La noche se cernía sobre nosotros, pero estábamos decididos a no descansar hasta que encontráramos al asesino y lo hiciéramos pagar por sus crímenes. La adrenalina me corría por las venas, y mi corazón latía con fuerza, listo para enfrentar cualquier peligro que se interpusiera en nuestro camino. Juntos, estábamos listos para enfrentar lo que viniera, listos para hacer justicia y proteger a aquellos que no podían defenderse. La oscuridad de la noche se convirtió en nuestra aliada, y nos sumergimos en ella, listos para enfrentar lo que viniera. La búsqueda había comenzado, y nada podría detenernos ahora. La determinación y la rabia nos impulsaban, y estábamos decididos a encontrar al asesino y hacer que pagara por sus crímenes. en_results_raw: the constable, to the room where the body lay, and as I entered, I was struck by the somber atmosphere that pervaded the space. The room was dimly lit, with only a faint light emanating from a small window high above, casting an eerie glow over the scene. The body, wrapped in a white shroud, lay on a simple wooden table, its presence seeming to draw all attention towards it. I felt a sense of morbid curiosity wash over me as I approached the table, my eyes fixed on the lifeless form. The constable, noticing my fascination, cautioned me to be careful, warning that the sight might be too much for me to bear. I nodded, trying to compose myself, but my heart was racing with anticipation. As I drew closer, I could see the faint outline of a face, pale and still, with eyes that seemed to stare into the very soul. The air was heavy with the scent of death, and I felt a shiver run down my spine. Mr. Kirwin, observing my reaction, seemed to be studying me intently, his eyes searching for any sign of weakness or distress. I tried to steel myself, to prepare for what was to come, but I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being drawn into a world from which there was no return. The silence in the room was oppressive, punctuated only by the faint creaking of the old wooden floorboards beneath my feet. I felt a sense of trepidation building inside me, a sense of foreboding that something was about to unfold, something that would change me forever.

es_second_half: varias otras personas me condujeron hasta la posada. Al entrar, me detuve en la puerta y miré hacia el interior, sintiendo un nudo en la garganta. El magistrado se detuvo a mi lado y me puso una mano en el hombro, como si quisiera ofrecerme consuelo. El aire de la habitación era frío y silencioso, y el único sonido que se escuchaba era el de mi propia respiración. Me acerqué lentamente al cuerpo, sintiendo una sensación de horror y tristeza que me oprimía el pecho. El rostro de mi hermano estaba pálido y tranquilo, y sus ojos estaban cerrados. Me sentí invadido por una oleada de recuerdos de nuestra infancia, de nuestras risas y nuestros secretos compartidos. Me acerqué un poco más y toqué su mano, sintiendo un escalofrío al contacto con su piel fría. El magistrado me habló en voz baja, recordándome que debía ser fuerte y que debía enfrentar la verdad. Pero yo no podía dejar de pensar en la forma en que había muerto, en la violencia y la crueldad que había sido utilizada contra él. Me sentí abrumado por la sensación de impotencia y de pérdida, y no pude evitar preguntarme si alguien más había sido responsable de su muerte. El magistrado me miró con compasión y me dijo que no había pruebas de que alguien más hubiera estado involucrado, pero yo no podía creerlo. La duda y la incertidumbre se apoderaron de mí, y me sentí perdido en un mundo que parecía haberse vuelto loco.

es_results_raw: <output>El viaje fue agotador, pero no pude permitirme el lujo de descansar, ya que el juicio se acercaba y cada hora contaba. Al llegar a la ciudad, me recibió el señor Kirwin con una sonrisa tranquilizadora, aunque pude ver en sus ojos una preocupación que no lograba disimular. Me aseguró que todo estaría bien, que había preparado un plan sólido para mi defensa y que estaba seguro de que saldría absuelto. Sin embargo, yo no estaba tan seguro. La evidencia en su contra era abrumadora y no podía evitar sentir un nudo en el estómago cada vez que pensaba en el veredicto del jurado. El señor Kirwin me explicó que había convocado a varios testigos que podrían testificar a mi favor, pero no podía evitar sentir una sensación de desesperanza. ¿Qué posibilidades tenía de salir libre después de todo lo que había pasado? La duda me perseguía constantemente, y no podía evitar preguntarme si había cometido un error al confiar en él. A pesar de todo, me esforcé por mantener la calma y confiar en que el señor Kirwin sabía lo que estaba haciendo. La noche anterior al juicio, me acosté con la mente en blanco, intentando no pensar en lo que podría suceder al día siguiente. Pero no pude evitar preguntarme qué sería lo peor que podría pasar. ¿Un veredicto de culpabilidad? ¿Una condena a prisión? ¿O algo aún peor? La incertidumbre me mantuvo despierto durante horas, hasta que finalmente me quedé dormido, exhausto y angustiado. Al día siguiente, me desperté temprano, con la sensación de que algo malo iba a suceder. El señor Kirwin me esperaba en la puerta de mi habitación, con una sonrisa firme en el rostro. "Vamos, amigo mío", me dijo. "Es hora de enfrentar a la justicia". Me levanté y me vestí con la ayuda de mi abogado, sintiendo un nudo en el estómago que no parecía disminuir. El juicio comenzó con un silencio tenso, y yo me senté en el banquillo de los acusados, sintiendo los ojos de todos los presentes en mí. El señor Kirwin se puso de pie y comenzó a hablar, su voz firme y convincente. "Señoría, mi cliente es inocente", dijo. "La evidencia presentada contra él es circunstancial y no hay pruebas concluyentes que lo vinculen con el crimen". El fiscal se puso de pie y comenzó a contradecir al señor Kirwin, presentando pruebas y testigos que parecían incriminarme. El juicio se desarrolló de manera tensa, con ambos lados presentando sus argumentos y pruebas. Al final, el jurado se retiró a deliberar, y yo me quedé sentado en el banquillo, sintiendo un nudo en el estómago que parecía crecer con cada minuto que pasaba. Finalmente, el forense llamó a la sala y el jurado regresó con un veredicto. Yo me levanté, preparado para lo peor, pero el señor Kirwin me sonrió y me dijo: "No te preocupes, amigo mío. Estoy seguro de que saldrás libre". Pero cuando el forense leyó el veredicto, mi corazón se detuvo. "El jurado encuentra al acusado... inocente". La sala estalló en aplausos y risas, y yo me quedé sentado en el banquillo, sin poder creer lo que había escuchado. Había sido absuelto. Me levanté y me dirigí hacia el señor Kirwin, abrazándolo con fuerza. "Gracias", le dije, con lágrimas en los ojos. "Gracias por creer en mí". El señor Kirwin sonrió y me abrazó a su vez. "No hay de qué, amigo mío", dijo. "Eres inocente y siempre lo has sido". Me sentí liberado, como si un peso enorme hubiera sido levantado de mis hombros. Había sido absuelto, y podía

He saw me as a son, freed from the shackles of prison, but I saw myself as a man, forever trapped in a living nightmare. The thought sent a shiver down my spine, and I knew that I would never be able to escape the darkness that had consumed me. es_results_raw: <output>de felicidad, yo no podía dejar de pensar en la mirada de mi víctima, en la sangre que había derramado y en la vida que había truncado. Mi padre, con su optimismo inquebrantable, me decía que todo había pasado y que debía olvidar, pero yo sabía que no era tan fácil. La memoria de aquel día se había grabado a fuego en mi mente, y cada vez que cerraba los ojos, veía la escena de nuevo. Me preguntaba si alguna vez podría encontrar la paz, si alguna vez podría olvidar el peso de la culpa que me oprimía el pecho. La libertad que me habían devuelto era un recuerdo lejano, un sueño que se desvanecía con cada paso que daba en la calle. La gente que me rodeaba parecía ignorar mi presencia, como si yo fuera un fantasma que vagaba por el mundo sin pertenecer a él. Me sentía solo, perdido en un mar de personas que no me conocían, que no sabían lo que había pasado. Mi padre me decía que debía seguir adelante, que debía intentar reconstruir mi vida, pero yo no sabía si era posible. La sombra de mi pasado me perseguía a cada paso, y no podía evitar preguntarme si alguna vez podría escapar de ella. en_second_half: should be at peace and his power over me be at an end. If he were vanquished, I should be a free man. Alas! What freedom? Such as the peasant enjoys when his family have been massacred before his eyes, his cottage burnt, his lands laid waste, and he is turned adrift, homeless, penniless, and alone, but free. Such would be my liberty except that in my Elizabeth I possessed a treasure, alas, balanced by those horrors of remorse and guilt which would pursue me until death.

La respuesta era simple: mi amor por ella, mi prometida, la única persona que había logrado ver más allá de la máscara que me había creado el bellaco. Mi padre me había dicho que no debía creer en supersticiones, que no debía dejar que el miedo me consumiera, pero yo no podía evitar sentir que algo malo estaba a punto de suceder. en_first_half: You have read this strange and terrific story, Margaret; and do you not feel your blood congeal with horror, like that which even now curdles mine? Sometimes, seized with sudden agony, he could not continue his tale; at others, his voice broken, yet piercing, uttered with difficulty the words so replete with anguish. His fine and lovely eyes were now lighted
en_second_half: up with indignation, now subdued to downcast sorrow and quenched in infinite wretchedness. Sometimes he commanded his countenance and tones and related the most horrible incidents with a tranquil voice, suppressing every mark of agitation; then, like a volcano bursting forth, his face would suddenly change to an expression of the wildest rage as he shrieked out imprecations on his persecutor.
en_results: with a wild and unearthly gleam, as if the very spirits of the dead were stirring within them, and his usually calm and composed countenance was now distorted by a ghastly and unutterable terror. The fire crackled and spat in the hearth, casting flickering shadows upon the walls, and the wind howled outside like a chorus of lost souls, as if it too were drawn into the vortex of his dark and troubled
en_results_raw: with a wild and unearthly gleam, as if the very spirits of the dead were stirring within them, and his usually calm and composed countenance was now distorted by a ghastly and unutterable terror. The fire crackled and spat in the hearth, casting flickering shadows upon the walls, and the wind howled outside like a chorus of lost souls, as if it too were drawn into the vortex of his dark and troubled mind. His words, though halting and labored, seemed to come from the very depths of his being, and I felt my own heart heavy with a sense of foreboding, as if I were being drawn into a realm from which there was no return. And yet, I could not look away, transfixed by the intensity of his gaze, as he spoke of the unspeakable things that had befallen him, and the unutterable horrors that still haunted him to this day.

en_first_half: And what, Margaret, will be the state of your mind? You will not hear of my destruction, and you will anxiously await my return. Years will pass, and you will have visitings of despair and yet be tortured by hope.
en_second_half: Oh! My beloved sister, the sickening failing of your heart-felt expectations is, in prospect, more terrible to me than my own death. But you have a husband and lovely children; you may be happy. Heaven bless you and make you so!
en_results: . The weight of uncertainty will bear down upon you, a constant reminder of the unknown fate that has befallen me. Your days will be filled with the ache of longing, the nights with the haunting memories of our time together. You
en_results_raw: And what, Margaret, will be the state of your mind? You will not hear of my destruction, and you will anxiously await my return. Years will pass, and you will have visitings of despair and yet be tortured by hope. The weight of uncertainty will bear down upon you, a constant reminder of the unknown fate that has befallen me. Your days will be filled with the ache of longing, the nights with the haunting memories of our time together. You will search for solace in the familiar routines of life, but they will offer little comfort. The world outside will seem dull and grey, a pale imitation of the vibrant colors that once danced in your eyes when I was by your side. And still, you will hold on to the glimmer of hope, a spark that refuses to be extinguished, a flame that flickers with every whispered rumor, every faint hint of a possibility that I may yet return to you.

es_second_half: horrible desilusión de tus esperanzas me resulta más terrible aún que mi propia muerte. Pero tienes a tu marido y a tus hermosos hijos; y puedes ser feliz. ¡Que el cielo te bendiga, y permita que lo seas!

en_first_half: September 9th, the ice began to move, and roarings like thunder were heard at a distance as the islands split and cracked in every direction. We were in the most imminent peril, but as we could only remain passive, my chief attention was occupied by my unfortunate guest whose illness increased in such a degree that he was entirely confined to his bed.
